Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Address: Nellibear, Sask.
Birthplace: Aberdeen, Scotland

19. **YOU IN JUNE 1911**

My wife and I have no money, nothing to sell and no food in the house. We wear foreign clothes and live in a house in England. We have no money to buy food or clothes.

By the way, I want to use all my skills once more again.
16. **CHILDREN'S DIETARY NEEDS**

   In the early days of the Great Depression, the children's diet was often lacking in essential nutrients. The following suggestions may help improve their diet:

   - **Breakfast:** Include eggs, milk, bread, and fruit.
   - **Lunch:** Include meat, vegetables, and a salad.
   - **Dinner:** Include fish, potatoes, and vegetables.

   Remember to include plenty of fresh fruits and vegetables in their diet.

17. **FOOD DONATIONS**

   If you have extra food, consider donating it to local food banks or soup kitchens. This will help those in need.

18. **EMERGENCY FOOD SUPPLIES**

   Keep emergency food supplies on hand in case of emergencies. This includes non-perishable foods such as canned goods, dried fruits, and nuts.

19. **LOCAL FOOD BANKS**

   Check with local food banks to see what they need most. They may be able to provide you with information on how to donate food.

---

**Note:** The above suggestions are based on general dietary recommendations. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional before making any significant changes to a child's diet.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the past.

In the early days, we used to cook our own food over an open fire. We would boil water in a kettle and then heat it over the fire. We would also use a cast-iron skillet to fry eggs and pancakes. We would also use a wood stove to heat our house.

21. Have you begun to rely on purchased foods or prepared foods instead of home-prepared foods? (Give any details and dates.)

Not until 1915 when we moved into our new house. We started to buy canned goods and other packaged foods.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and acquiring foods in other ways. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of paper if more space is needed.)

In the spring of 1904-05, we had no money, so we worked on the farm. We raised our own vegetables and fruits. We also bought some meat at the local store. We would also go to the market to buy eggs and milk. We would also buy bread and butter at the local store.

The chief items we bought were butter ($1.25), tea ($1.00), sugar ($0.30).
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown, and how preserved foods? (Give as many dates and details as possible.)

Not until 1915 when we started growing our own vegetables in the garden. We also started canning and preserving our own fruits and vegetables.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and acquiring foods. In other words, describe pioneer life in eastern Canada, including its not mentioned above, quality, methods of transportation, prices, problems, shortages, etc., including other details. (Use back of paper if more space needed.)

As the owner of the store, I had no money, so my family and I worked hard to earn a living. We lived in a small house on the side of the road, which was our only shelter. We had to work long hours to earn enough money to buy food and other necessities. We also had to grow our own vegetables and fruits to survive.

In 1905-06, we had no money, so my family and I worked hard to earn a living. We lived in a small house on the side of the road, which was our only shelter. We had to work long hours to earn enough money to buy food and other necessities. We also had to grow our own vegetables and fruits to survive.

On the early days, the store kept track of what materials were bought and sold. The chief items were butter ($2.50 per lb.), sugar ($1.00 per lb.), and coffee ($3.00 per lb.).
Along about 1906 the free homesteads in this district were being taken up quite fast. Some neighbor of ours had lived in Winnipeg and knew a store keeper there called Store.

So we got together and every few months we sent a joint club order and got our groceries at a very small increase in price over wholesale prices, as these goods were shipped in unbroken boxes. (cartons were not used then)

These goods were shipped to South Quappelle (about 60 miles from here) and one of us would go there and fetch them.
